name: NgControl
comment: The NgControl class is a super-class for handling info and error states between inner controls and models. NgControl will automatically apply the associated CSS classes for the error and info states that are applied as well as status flags. NgControl is used with the form and fieldset as well as all other directives that are used for user input with NgModel.

errorStates.name: errorStates
errorStates.comment: The list of errors present on the control represented by an error name and an inner control instance.

infoStates.name: infoStates
infoStates.comment: The list of info messages present on the control represented by an state name and an inner control instance.

submitted.name: submitted
submitted.comment: Whether or not the form has been submitted yet.

validSubmit.name: validSubmit
validSubmit.comment: Whether or not the form was valid when last submitted.

invalidSubmit.name: invalidSubmit
invalidSubmit.comment: Whether or not the form was invalid when last submitted.

element.name: element
element.comment: Whether or not the form was invalid when last submitted.

valid.name: valid
valid.comment: A control is considered valid if all inner models are valid.

invalid.name: invalid
invalid.comment: A control is considered invalid if any inner models are invalid.

pristine.name: pristine
pristine.comment: Whether or not the control's or model's data has not been changed.

dirty.name: dirty
dirty.comment: Whether or not the control's or model's data has been changed.

untouched.name: untouched
untouched.comment: Whether or not the control/model has not been interacted with by the user.

touched.name: touched
touched.comment: Whether or not the control/model has been interacted with by the user.

reset.name: reset
reset.comment: Resets the form and inner models to their pristine state.

addControl.name: addControl
addControl.comment:
Registers a form control into the form for validation.

  • angular-directive.NgControl.addControl.control - The form control which will be registered (see angular-directive.NgControl).

removeControl.name: removeControl
removeControl.comment:
De-registers a form control from the list of controls associated with the form.

  • angular-directive.NgControl.removeControl.control - The form control which will be de-registered (see angular-directive.NgControl).

removeStates.name: removeStates
removeStates.comment:
Clears all the info and error states that are associated with the control.

  • angular-directive.NgControl.removeStates.control - The form control which will be cleared of all state (see angular-directive.NgControl).

hasErrorState.name: hasErrorState
hasErrorState.comment:
Whether or not the control contains the given error.

  • angular-directive.NgControl.hasErrorState.errorName - The name of the error (e.g. ng-required, ng-pattern, etc...)

addErrorState.name: addErrorState
addErrorState.comment:
Adds the given childControl/errorName to the list of errors present on the control. Once added all associated parent controls will be registered with the error as well.

  • angular-directive.NgControl.addErrorState.childControl - The child control that contains the error.
  • angular-directive.NgControl.addErrorState.errorName - The name of the given error (e.g. ng-required, ng-pattern, etc...).

removeErrorState.name: removeErrorState
removeErrorState.comment:
Removes the given childControl/errorName from the list of errors present on the control. Once removed the control will update any parent controls depending if error is not present on any other inner controls and or models.

  • angular-directive.NgControl.removeErrorState.childControl - The child control that contains the error.
  • angular-directive.NgControl.removeErrorState.errorName - The name of the given error (e.g. ng-required, ng-pattern, etc...).

addInfoState.name: addInfoState
addInfoState.comment:
Registers a non-error state on the control with the given childControl/stateName data. Once added the control will also add the same data to any associated parent controls.

  • angular-directive.NgControl.addInfoState.childControl - The child control that contains the error.
  • angular-directive.NgControl.addInfoState.stateName - The name of the given error (e.g. ng-required, ng-pattern, etc...).

removeInfoState.name: removeInfoState
removeInfoState.comment:
De-registers the provided state on the control with the given childControl. The state will be fully removed from the control if all of the inner controls/models also do not contain the state. If so then the state will also be attempted to be removed from the associated parent controls.

  • angular-directive.NgControl.removeInfoState.childControl - The child control that contains the error.
  • angular-directive.NgControl.removeInfoState.stateName - The name of the given error (e.g. ng-required, ng-pattern, etc...).

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides angular-directive.NgControl.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and angular-directive.NgControl.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the angular-directive.NgControl.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
angular-directive.NgControl.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to angular-directive.NgControl.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If angular-directive.NgControl.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of angular-directive.NgControl.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
